questions.text: A 24-year primigravida at 36 weeks complained of decreased fetal movements since 1 day. The following test was ordered. What is this test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Non-Stress Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an NST, a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with fetal movements is recorded During fetal movements, the fetal heart rate increases (Acceleration) A reactive NST: Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm 2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins Good variability No decelerations
  • ➤ In an NST, a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with fetal movements is recorded
  • ➤ During fetal movements, the fetal heart rate increases (Acceleration)
  • ➤ A reactive NST: Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm 2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins Good variability No decelerations
  • ➤ Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm 2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins Good variability No decelerations
  • ➤ Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm
  • ➤ 2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins
  • ➤ Good variability
  • ➤ No decelerations
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 22-year G2P1 with a history of a previous term still birth at term is now 37 weeks. She complains of decreased fetal movements of 2 days. A Biophysical profile is ordered. All are components of the Biophysical profile except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Umbilical Artery Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows: Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows: Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Nonstress test
  • ➤ Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • ➤ Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida with preeclampsia is undergoing a Biophysical profile. The image shows which component of this test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Amniotic fluid volume

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image is showing the measurement of amniotic fluid volume
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Fetal movement Fetal tone Fetal breathing movement
  • • Fetal movement
  • • Fetal tone
  • • Fetal breathing movement
  • • All these options are components of the biophysical profile and are seen on real time ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows: Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows: Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Nonstress test
  • ➤ Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • ➤ Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ *This image shows the measurement of amniotic fluid being taken (single vertical pocket)
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338

questions.text: An intern is on rounds in the antenatal ward. He has been asked to check the fetal heart rate of all the term antenatal patients. What is the normal fetal heart rate at term?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 110 – 160 bpm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal fetal heart rate at term is 110-160 bpm
  • ➤ The normal fetal heart rate at term is 110-160 bpm
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 25-year G2P1 with twin pregnancy has been diagnosed with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus. She is now 32 weeks. All are methods of antepartum fetal surveillance in her except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fetal movement count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal movement count is not a reliable method of fetal surveillance in twin pregnancies Maternal perception of fetal movements may be reduced with Fetal sleep Fetal CNS anomalies Anterior placenta Obesity Chronic smoking Hypoxia
  • ➤ Fetal movement count is not a reliable method of fetal surveillance in twin pregnancies
  • ➤ Maternal perception of fetal movements may be reduced with Fetal sleep Fetal CNS anomalies Anterior placenta Obesity Chronic smoking Hypoxia
  • ➤ Fetal sleep Fetal CNS anomalies Anterior placenta Obesity Chronic smoking Hypoxia
  • ➤ Fetal sleep
  • ➤ Fetal CNS anomalies
  • ➤ Anterior placenta
  • ➤ Obesity
  • ➤ Chronic smoking
  • ➤ Hypoxia
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9 th edition

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. AFI + NST

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Modified biophysical profile (BPP) consists of a Non-Stress Test (NST) and Ultrasound determination of amniotic fluid volume (Amniotic fluid index - AFI).
  • ➤ Modified biophysical profile (BPP) consists of a Non-Stress Test (NST) and Ultrasound determination of amniotic fluid volume (Amniotic fluid index - AFI).
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 24-year primi presents at 36 weeks. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 32 weeks, the symphysio-fundal height is 31 cm, the fetus is in cephalic presentation and the fetal heart rate is 140 bpm. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ultrasound for biometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Causes of the uterine height less than the period of gestation:
  • ➤ Fetal growth restriction Oligohydramnios Intra uterine fetal death Wrong dates Transverse lie
  • ➤ Fetal growth restriction
  • ➤ Oligohydramnios
  • ➤ Intra uterine fetal death
  • ➤ Wrong dates
  • ➤ Transverse lie
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 852, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 852, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1 presents at 37 weeks. A Non -Stress Test is done. The following trace is seen. What is the next best management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Call her after 1 week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Features of a reactive NST are
  • ➤ Features of a reactive NST are
  • ➤ The baseline FHR is normal (110-160 bpm) Beat to beat variability is normal (5 - 25 bpm) There are > 2 accelerations in a 20-minute trace There are no decelerations
  • ➤ The baseline FHR is normal (110-160 bpm)
  • ➤ Beat to beat variability is normal (5 - 25 bpm)
  • ➤ There are > 2 accelerations in a 20-minute trace
  • ➤ There are no decelerations
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 26-year lady with mild pre-eclampsia presents at 32 weeks. On abdominal examination, the uterus corresponds to 28 weeks. Fetal heart rate is 132 bpm. An ultrasound is advised. The following image shows an umbilical artery Doppler. What is your interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Absent diastolic flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 854, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 854, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the Non-Stress Test ?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart rate of a fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily decelerate with fetal movement.

options.label: B
options.text: Heart rate reactivity is believed to be a good indicator of normal fetal autonomic function

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of reactivity can be associated with any form of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis.

options.label: D
options.text: The nonstress test of the neurologically healthy preterm fetus is frequently non-reactive in up to 50% of tests from 24 to 28 weeks of gestation.

questions.correct_answer: A. The heart rate of a fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily decelerate with fetal movement.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The heart rate of a fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily decelerate with fetal movement.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the nonstress test, the heart rate of the fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily accelerate with fetal movement
  • ➤ Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 465
  • ➤ Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 465

questions.text: In the biophysical profile, one of the components is fetal movement. This is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: One or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: Two or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: Four or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

questions.correct_answer: C. Three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
  • ➤ Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid). Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”. A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ Nonstress test
  • ➤ Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • ➤ Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”. A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ A score of 8 or 10: Normal
  • ➤ A score of 6: Equivocal
  • ➤ A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal
  • ➤ The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338

questions.text: All are true regarding umbilical artery Doppler as a modality of antepartum fetal surveillance except?

options.label: A
options.text: The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

options.label: B
options.text: Flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery of fetuses with normal growth differ from those of fetuses with growth restriction.

options.label: C
options.text: The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has a low-velocity diastolic flow.

options.label: D
options.text: With extreme intrauterine growth restriction, the diastolic flow may be absent or even reversed

questions.correct_answer: C. The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has a low-velocity diastolic flow.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has a low-velocity diastolic flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has high-velocity diastolic flow, while in cases of intrauterine growth restriction, the umbilical artery diastolic flow is diminished
  • ➤ Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 213
  • ➤ Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 213

questions.text: A 26-year G2P1 with a previous LSCS presents at 35 weeks with fetal growth restriction. She complains of decreased fetal movements for 1 day. A biophysical profile is ordered, and the Manning score is 2. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat NST after hydration, Oxygen and left lateral position

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat Biophysical profile after hydration, oxygen and left lateral position

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Emergency LSCS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows: Nonstress test Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes) Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes) Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid). Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”. A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
  • ➤ Nonstress test
  • ➤ Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • ➤ Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • ➤ Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • ➤ Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”. A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ A score of 8 or 10: Normal A score of 6: Equivocal A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ A score of 8 or 10: Normal
  • ➤ A score of 6: Equivocal
  • ➤ A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal
  • ➤ The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25 th edition pg 338

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida presents to the OPD at 37 weeks complaining of decreased fetal movement. An NST is taken which shows the following. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Extend the trace for another 20 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure the patient and call her after 1 week

questions.correct_answer: A. Extend the trace for another 20 minutes
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Extend the trace for another 20 minutes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loss of reactivity may result from fetal sleep cycle or any cause of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis. If the NST is non reassuring, it should be continued for a further 20 minutes or a Vibro-acoustic stimulation is done to reduce the fetal sleep state from quiet (non-REM) to active (REM) sleep.
  • ➤ Loss of reactivity may result from fetal sleep cycle or any cause of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis.
  • ➤ If the NST is non reassuring, it should be continued for a further 20 minutes or a Vibro-acoustic stimulation is done to reduce the fetal sleep state from quiet (non-REM) to active (REM) sleep.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9 th edition

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is defined as a single deepest pocket less than?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 2 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amniotic Fluid can be measured by
  • ➤ Amniotic Fluid can be measured by
  • ➤ Amniotic Fluid Index Single deepest pocket
  • ➤ Amniotic Fluid Index
  • ➤ Single deepest pocket
  • ➤ Single Deepest Pocket
  • ➤ Single Deepest Pocket
  • ➤ Or Maximal vertical pocket The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman. The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured. Unit of measurement: cm/ mm The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm More useful in 2 nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation.
  • ➤ Or Maximal vertical pocket
  • ➤ The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman.
  • ➤ The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured.
  • ➤ Unit of measurement: cm/ mm
  • ➤ The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm
  • ➤ More useful in 2 nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: An intern is taking rounds in the antenatal ward. He has been asked to auscultate the fetal hearts of all pregnant patients. Above which gestational age, will he be able to hear the FHR by a stethoscope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fetal heart can be auscultated by the bell of a stethoscope by 20 weeks gestation The fetal heart can be auscultated with a handheld Doppler after 14 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ The fetal heart can be auscultated by the bell of a stethoscope by 20 weeks gestation
  • ➤ The fetal heart can be auscultated with a handheld Doppler after 14 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ R ef: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ R
  • ➤ ef: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida is in active labor. On the CTG, the following CTG is observed. What is the likely cervical dilatation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 10 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Types of decelerations on a Cardiotocograph (CTG)
  • ➤ 1. Early Deceleration:
  • ➤ The nadir of the deceleration corresponds to the peak of contraction Due to head compression Common in 2 nd stage of labor (full dilatation of the cervix)
  • ➤ The nadir of the deceleration corresponds to the peak of contraction
  • ➤ Due to head compression
  • ➤ Common in 2 nd stage of labor (full dilatation of the cervix)
  • ➤ 2. Late Decelerations:
  • ➤ The nadir (dip) of the deceleration occurs after the peak of contraction Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency (fetal distress/ hypoxia) It is an ominous sign
  • ➤ The nadir (dip) of the deceleration occurs after the peak of contraction
  • ➤ Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency (fetal distress/ hypoxia)
  • ➤ It is an ominous sign
  • ➤ 3. Variable Decelerations
  • ➤ There is no fixed relationship between decelerations and the uterine contractions Seen due to cord compression (oligohydramnios) Significant if
  • ➤ There is no fixed relationship between decelerations and the uterine contractions
  • ➤ Seen due to cord compression (oligohydramnios)
  • ➤ Significant if
  • ➤ Persistent FHR < 70 bpm > 60 sec
  • ➤ Persistent
  • ➤ FHR < 70 bpm > 60 sec
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 468, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 468, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida is in active labor at 41 weeks. The CTG shows the following trace at 6 cm cervical dilatation. This indicates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Fetal Hypoxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Late decelerations are a sign of utero placental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia
  • ➤ Late decelerations are a sign of utero placental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 466, Williams 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 466, Williams 25 th edition

questions.text: Which is not a method of intrapartum fetal monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Amniotic Fluid Index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methods of intrapartum fetal monitoring include
  • ➤ Intermittent auscultation Electronic fetal heart rate monitoring External Internal Fetal scalp blood stimulation Vibroacoustic stimulation Intrapartum umbilical artery doppler Fetal scalp blood pH Fetal scalp blood lactate Fetal ECG Fetal pulse oximetry Near Infrared Spectroscopy
  • ➤ Intermittent auscultation
  • ➤ Electronic fetal heart rate monitoring External Internal
  • ➤ External Internal
  • ➤ External
  • ➤ Internal
  • ➤ Fetal scalp blood stimulation
  • ➤ Vibroacoustic stimulation
  • ➤ Intrapartum umbilical artery doppler
  • ➤ Fetal scalp blood pH
  • ➤ Fetal scalp blood lactate
  • ➤ Fetal ECG
  • ➤ Fetal pulse oximetry
  • ➤ Near Infrared Spectroscopy
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 567, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 567, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: A 34y G2 is in labor. Due to persistent late decelerations, a fetal scalp blood sample is taken. Which is incorrect regarding fetal scalp blood sampling?

options.label: A
options.text: A pH < 7.20 indicates fetal hypoxia and necessitates urgent delivery

options.label: B
options.text: A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L

options.label: C
options.text: It can be done only when the woman is in active labor with ruptured membranes

options.label: D
options.text: It is contra-indicated in < 34 weeks period of gestation

questions.correct_answer: B. A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A normal fetal lactate level is > 4.8 mmol/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal Scalp Blood Sampling
  • ➤ Indicated in abnormal CTG to confirm fetal hypoxia Values < 7.20: Fetal acidosis and necessitates urgent delivery pH between 7.21 and 7.25: borderline; Repeat within 30 minutes pH > 7.25: Reassuring Procedure Mother in left lateral position An illuminated plastic cone inserted through the dilated cervix (at least 4 – 5 cm dilatation required) An incision of 2 mm made with a lancet 35μl blood is adequate for estimation of pH Contra-Indications When spontaneous delivery is imminent Preterm (< 34 weeks) Fetal coagulation defects Maternal infection (HIV, Hepatitis, Herpes simplex) Fetal lactate measurements require lesser amount of blood (7 μl). Normal fetal lactate: ≤ 4.1 mmol/l Borderline: 4.2 – 4.8 mmol/l Abnormal: > 4.9 mmol/l
  • ➤ Indicated in abnormal CTG to confirm fetal hypoxia
  • ➤ Values < 7.20: Fetal acidosis and necessitates urgent delivery pH between 7.21 and 7.25: borderline; Repeat within 30 minutes pH > 7.25: Reassuring
  • ➤ < 7.20: Fetal acidosis and necessitates urgent delivery pH between 7.21 and 7.25: borderline; Repeat within 30 minutes pH > 7.25: Reassuring
  • ➤ < 7.20: Fetal acidosis and necessitates urgent delivery
  • ➤ pH between 7.21 and 7.25: borderline; Repeat within 30 minutes
  • ➤ pH > 7.25: Reassuring
  • ➤ Procedure Mother in left lateral position An illuminated plastic cone inserted through the dilated cervix (at least 4 – 5 cm dilatation required) An incision of 2 mm made with a lancet 35μl blood is adequate for estimation of pH
  • ➤ Mother in left lateral position An illuminated plastic cone inserted through the dilated cervix (at least 4 – 5 cm dilatation required) An incision of 2 mm made with a lancet 35μl blood is adequate for estimation of pH
  • ➤ Mother in left lateral position
  • ➤ An illuminated plastic cone inserted through the dilated cervix (at least 4 – 5 cm dilatation required)
  • ➤ An incision of 2 mm made with a lancet
  • ➤ 35μl blood is adequate for estimation of pH
  • ➤ Contra-Indications When spontaneous delivery is imminent Preterm (< 34 weeks) Fetal coagulation defects Maternal infection (HIV, Hepatitis, Herpes simplex)
  • ➤ When spontaneous delivery is imminent Preterm (< 34 weeks) Fetal coagulation defects Maternal infection (HIV, Hepatitis, Herpes simplex)
  • ➤ When spontaneous delivery is imminent

questions.text: Which of the below mentioned causes will not cause the fetal heart rate pattern shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Utero placental insufficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding late decelerations?

options.label: A
options.text: The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively

options.label: B
options.text: The onset of the deceleration occurs before the beginning of the contraction, but the nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the peak and ending of the contraction, respectively

options.label: C
options.text: The onset and nadir of the deceleration occur before the beginning and peak of the contraction, respectively, but the recovery of the deceleration occurs after the ending of the contraction

options.label: D
options.text: The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur before the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively

questions.correct_answer: A. The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Late Decelerations
  • • Late Decelerations
  • • The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively The deceleration reaches its nadir within 30 seconds of its onset Causes Uteroplacental insufficiency Maternal hypotension Uterine hyperactivity
  • • The onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the beginning, peak and ending of the contraction, respectively
  • • The deceleration reaches its nadir within 30 seconds of its onset
  • • Causes Uteroplacental insufficiency Maternal hypotension Uterine hyperactivity
  • • Uteroplacental insufficiency Maternal hypotension Uterine hyperactivity
  • • Uteroplacental insufficiency
  • • Maternal hypotension
  • • Uterine hyperactivity

questions.text: A 22y primi in labor at 38 weeks has ruptured her membranes spontaneously at 5 cm dilatation. On the CTG, the below image is seen. The most likely cause is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cord prolapse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Prolonged Deceleration
  • • Defined as an isolated deceleration ≥ 15 bpm that lasts ≥ 2 minutes but < 10 mins from onset to return to baseline Causes Epidural or spinal anesthesia Placental abruption Cord prolapse Umbilical cord knots Eclampsia Epilepsy Application of a fetal scalp electrode Maternal Valsalva manuever In the scenario given, the deceleration occurs after rupture of membranes. 2 common causes of prolonged deceleration following rupture of membranes are: cord prolapse and abruptio placentae.
  • • Defined as an isolated deceleration ≥ 15 bpm that lasts ≥ 2 minutes but < 10 mins from onset to return to baseline
  • • Causes Epidural or spinal anesthesia Placental abruption Cord prolapse Umbilical cord knots Eclampsia Epilepsy Application of a fetal scalp electrode Maternal Valsalva manuever
  • • Epidural or spinal anesthesia Placental abruption Cord prolapse Umbilical cord knots Eclampsia Epilepsy Application of a fetal scalp electrode Maternal Valsalva manuever
  • • Epidural or spinal anesthesia
  • • Placental abruption
  • • Cord prolapse
  • • Umbilical cord knots
  • • Eclampsia
  • • Epilepsy
  • • Application of a fetal scalp electrode
  • • Maternal Valsalva manuever
  • • In the scenario given, the deceleration occurs after rupture of membranes. 2 common causes of prolonged deceleration following rupture of membranes are: cord prolapse and abruptio placentae.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oligohydramnios: This will lead to variable decelerations Option B. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: In fetal hypoxia this would lead to late decelerations Option C. Head compression: This will result in early decelerations
  • • Option A. Oligohydramnios: This will lead to variable decelerations
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: In fetal hypoxia this would lead to late decelerations
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Head compression: This will result in early decelerations
  • • Option C.

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is in labor. At 5cm dilatation, a CTG taken shows late decelerations. A fetal scalp blood sample reveals a pH of 7.19. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat scalp blood pH within 30 mins

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrate the patient and start O2

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Immediate cesarean section
